questions.text:
A pediatric resident is preparing a presentation on neonatal mortality in India. She finds a dataset from the verbal autopsy report (2010-2013) and wants to understand the hierarchy of factors contributing to neonatal deaths. Based on this data, how would you arrange these factors from the most significant contributor to the least? [INICET NOV 2021]

 

  1. Prematurity and low birth weight
  2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia
  3. Congenital anomalies
  4. Sepsis
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1>2>4>3

 

The most significant factors contributing to neonatal mortality are arranged as follows: Prematurity and low birth weight, followed by birth injuries and birth asphyxia, then sepsis, and finally congenital anomalies.

 

1. Prematurity and low birth weight: These are the leading causes of neonatal mortality due to complications associated with underdevelopment.

 

2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia: These are significant contributors to neonatal deaths due to physical trauma and lack of oxygen during birth.

 

4. Sepsis: Infections are a major cause of death, particularly in the late neonatal period.

 

3. Congenital anomalies: These contribute to neonatal mortality but to a lesser extent compared to the other factors.

 

NNMR - Neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within completed 28 days after birth) per 1000 live births in that year

 

 

  • Early neonatal mortality (ENNM): Neonatal mortality in first week (1-7 days) of life
  • Late neonatal mortality (LNNM): Neonatal mortality in first to fourth week (8 – 28 days) of life
  • MCC of NNMR in India is preterm birth
    • MCC of ENNMR: Prematurity and congenital anomalies
    • MCC of LNNMR: Infections (diarrhea and tetanus)
  • As per 2022-23 data - India’s NNMR is 20 per 1000 live births
  • NNMR is directly related with birth weight and gestational age
  • NNMRboys >NNMRgirls 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of Neonatal mortality (0 – 4 weeks): 

 

  • Low birth weight and prematurity
  • Birth injury and difficult labour
  • Sepsis
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Hemolytic diseases of newborn
  • Conditions of placenta and cord
  • Diarrhoeal diseases
  • Acute respiratory infections
  • Tetanus

 

According to WHO, Preterm birth, intrapartum-related complications (birth asphyxia), infections and congenital defects are the leading causes of most neonatal deaths.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company has developed a novel diagnostic test for a rare metabolic disorder. In clinical trials, the test demonstrated a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.80. In a population where the prevalence of the disease is 30%, the test was applied to every participant. What is the probability that a person who tests negative truly does not have the disease? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 95%

 

  • It’s the Negative Predictive Value (NPV), which tells us the probability that a person with a negative test result truly doesn't have the disease.

 NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

  • Use a hypothetical cohort of 1000 people for easy calculation.

 

Given:

 

  • Disease prevalence = 30% = 300 people with the disease and 700 without the disease out of 1000.
  • Sensitivity = 0.90, so TP = 0.90 * 300 = 270 and FN = 300 - 270 = 30.
  • Specificity = 0.80, so TN = 0.80 * 700 = 560 and FP = 700 - 560 = 140.

 

Using the above formula:

 

NPV = 560 / (560 + 30) = 560 / 590 = 0.9491 or approximately 95%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Negative Predictive Value (NPV) represents the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease

choices.text: Trying to make them think for themselves

questions.text: In the bustling streets of Mumbai, a young filmmaker is working on a documentary about the impact of media on public opinion. During his interviews with several media experts, he encounters the term "propaganda" frequently. Intrigued, he decides to explore this concept further and learns that it plays a significant role in shaping public perception. In the context of media and communication, which of the following best describes the essence of "propaganda"?(FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Appeals to emotions

 

Propaganda refers to - trying to make them think for themselves, it appeals to emotions. Propaganda is a passively acquired knowledge, which by persuasive communication leads to change in belief and attitude (brain washing).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trying to make them think for themselves: This is more aligned with education and critical thinking, not propaganda.

 

Option B. Behavior centric: While propaganda aims to change behavior, its primary method is through emotional appeal rather than focusing on behavior itself.

 

Option C. Acquiring knowledge: Propaganda often involves passive acquisition of biased information, not the active pursuit of knowledge.

questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

questions.text: An individual experienced a dog bite. Both the person and the dog are up-to-date with their vaccinations. The person's medical history includes a splenectomy performed five years ago. What is the optimal course of action for managing this situation? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Amoxiclav

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate (Augmentin) is generally considered the first-line prophylactic treatment for animal bites.
  • Appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis as indicated should also be a part of caring for a patient who has sustained a dog bite, as well as local debridement and thorough cleaning of the wound

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Observation alone is not sufficient due to the risk of infection, especially in an asplenic individual.

 

Option C. Metronidazole: This antibiotic is not typically used as monotherapy for animal bites as it does not cover the range of bacteria commonly involved.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: While it has some coverage, it is not the first-line treatment for dog bites and lacks the broad coverage provided by amoxicillin/clavulanate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the optimal course of action for prophylactic treatment following a dog bite, especially in individuals with increased infection risk, such as those with a history of splenectomy.
  • Thorough wound care and appropriate prophylaxis for tetanus and rabies should also be part of the management plan.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation, you notice the different color-coded waste bins meticulously arranged by the nursing staff as per the hospital's waste management protocol. If you were to guide a new intern about the appropriate disposal of items, which item among the following would you instruct them to discard in the black bin? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Glove paper cover

 

  • The paper cover for gloves constitutes regular solid waste, which should be placed in the designated black bin.
  • All types of non-infectious general refuse, including food waste, paper waste, and mineral water bottles, ought to be deposited in the black bins.
  • Bedsheets and linens that are soiled and contaminated with blood or bodily fluids should be appropriately disposed of in the yellow bin.
  • Plastic materials that are recyclable, such as gloves and contaminated gloves, should be placed in the red bins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soiled linen bedsheet: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin for contaminated waste.

 

Option C. Gloves: Should be placed in the red bin for recyclable materials.

 

Option D. Contaminated gloves: Also go in the red bin for medical waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-infectious general refuse, such as glove paper covers, should be discarded in the black bin.

questions.text: During a medical ethics seminar, Dr. Sharma discussed a series of international declarations that guide medical professionals in upholding ethical principles in various scenarios. These declarations were born out of historical events and societal needs to ensure the welfare of patients and respect human rights. Can you match these declarations with their respective significance? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) I - C, II - D, III - A, IV - B

 

  • Geneva Declaration: It is primarily focused on the physician's dedication to the humanitarian goals of medicine, emphasizing the commitment of the medical profession to human welfare and ethics. This declaration is assigned significance C.
  • Oslo Declaration: It deals with issues surrounding therapeutic abortion, offering guidelines and ethical considerations for medical professionals when abortion is a factor in medical treatment. This declaration is assigned significance D.
  • Tokyo Declaration: Provides guidelines for physicians concerning the ethical treatment of detainees and prisoners, specifically regarding torture and other forms of cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. This declaration is assigned significance A.
  • Helsinki Declaration: A cornerstone document that outlines ethical principles for the medical community concerning human experimentation. This declaration provides comprehensive guidelines intended to protect the dignity, rights, safety, and well-being of research subjects. It is assigned significance B.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As a healthcare consultant in Uttar Pradesh working to improve maternal and child health outcomes, you need to address issues such as inadequate hygiene, lack of skilled staff, and outdated equipment in labor rooms of public health facilities. Which program should you recommend that is specifically designed to enhance the quality of labor rooms? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) LAQSHYA

 

LAQSHYA [Labour Room Quality Improvement Initiative] 

 

  • MoHFW launched LaQshya to improve the quality of care that is being provided to the pregnant mother in the Labor Room and Maternity Operation Theaters, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth
  • Aim: To reduce Maternal and newborn mortality & morbidity and stillbirths
  • Coverage: Govt Medical colleges & hospitals/District hospitals/FRU > 100 deliveries/month, High load CHC (>60 deliveries/month)

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ayushman Bharat: This is a broader health insurance scheme aimed at providing health cover to underprivileged families, not specifically focused on improving labor room conditions.

 

Option C. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Although this program provides free benefits to pregnant women and sick infants, it does not specifically target the improvement of labor room conditions.

 

Option D. Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This initiative is aimed at providing assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to pregnant women on the 9th of every month but does not specifically address labor room quality improvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recommending the LAQSHYA program is directly aligned with the need to overhaul the quality of labor rooms in public health facilities, targeting specific improvements in infrastructure, hygiene, and staff competencies to ensure safer childbirth experiences.

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.text: You are assessing the impact of a new series testing protocol on the performance characteristics of diagnostic tests for a specific disease. You need to explain to your team how this method affects the test's sensitivity and specificity. What would be the correct explanation? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN SERIES:

 

A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test; 2nd screening test is applied on those individuals only who test positive on the 1st screening test

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in series: Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in series: [Specificity (A) + Specificity (B)] – [Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)]

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN PARALLEL:

 

A population is subjected to two (or more) screening tests at the same time; each of the individuals is subjected to both (or all) screening tests

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: [Sensitivity (A) + Sensitivity (B)] – [Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)]
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Relative risk 

 

The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

 

 

Interpretation of RR

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attributable risk (AR):  is the difference in the risk of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, and represents the proportion of disease that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

Option B. Odds ratio (OR):  is the ratio of the odds of disease in the exposed group to the odds of disease in the non-exposed group.

 

Option D. Population attributable risk (PAR):  is the proportion of disease cases in the population that can be reduced if risk factor is modified or eliminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor
  • Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR)
  • Strength of association:
    • Relative risk (cohort study)
    • Odds ratio (case control study)

questions.text: Which of the following elements is not included in the provisions of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017, as per the WHO's mhGAP? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening of family members

 

  • The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 focuses on the rights and treatment of patients with mental illness, but it does not specifically include provisions for the screening of family members.
  • The Act covers various aspects such as the capacity to make healthcare decisions, advance directives, nominated representatives, types of admissions, bans on certain treatments (like direct ECT for minors and psychosurgery), decriminalization of suicide attempts, and regulations on restraints and seclusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mobilization of resources: The Act includes provisions related to the mobilization of resources for mental health services.

 

Option C. Social support: Social support is a crucial aspect of mental health care covered under the Act, ensuring that patients receive necessary support from family and community.

 

Option D. Interpersonal therapy: While specific therapies may not be explicitly listed, the Act does promote access to various mental health treatments, which can include interpersonal therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening of family members is not included in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017.

 

Additional Information

 

MENTAL HEALTHCARE ACT, 2017 (MHCA 2017)

 

  • Deals with rights of patients with mental illness and treatment delivery. Important clauses-

 

A. Capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision- Every person, including patients with mental illness, are assumed to have it if they can-

 

  • Can understand the information provided to them
  • Understand the consequences of their decisions
  • Can communicate their decision

 

B. Advance directive- Every person (not a minor) can make an advance directive in which he can mention-

 

  • How they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness
  • Applicable only if a person loses the capacity to take mental healthcare or treatment decisions
  • Duty of psychiatrist (or medical officer) to give treatment according to the advance directive
  • Doctor is not liable in case of unforeseen consequences while following the advance directive

 

C. Nominated representative (NR)-

 

  • Every person can appoint a nominated representative
  • In case of loss of capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision, NR would help in taking decisions about treatment

 

D. Admission- MHCA 2017 allows two types of admissions

 

  • Independent admissions- When the patient himself wants to get admitted
  • Supported admission (for a maximum of 30 days)- A person who has lost the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions and requires significant support from a nominated representative can be admitted under a “supported admission”

 

E. Ban on direct ECT

 

F. Ban on ECT for minors

 

G. Ban on psychosurgery

 

H. Decriminalisation of suicide attempt - Any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished

 

I. Restraints and seclusions - A patient can be physically restrained only-

 

  • If it is the only way to prevent harm to self or others
  • If authorised by a psychiatrist in charge

questions.text: As per United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, Targets for MMR and U5MR to be achieved by 2030 are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70 MMR, 25 U5MR

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were established in 2016 as a global agenda to be achieved by 2030. Among the 17 goals outlined, Goal 3 is specifically focused on health and well-being.

 

Under this goal:

 

  • Target 3.1 aims to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
  • Target 3.2 focuses on reducing the under-5 mortality rate (U5MR) to 25 per 1,000 live births and neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births.

 

These targets are part of a broader effort to improve health outcomes and ensure universal health coverage by 2030.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals aim to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to below 70 per 100,000 live births and the under-5 mortality rate to 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030.

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.text: A sensitive diagnostic test for a certain disease returns a positive result for a patient. What statement accurately describes the significance of a positive result from the sensitive test? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common

 

  • If a sensitive test yields a positive result, it indicates the presence of the disease, especially when the disease is prevalent.
  • The sensitivity of a screening test refers to its capacity to accurately identify individuals with the disease.
  • In simpler terms, sensitivity measures the test's capability to correctly spot true positives (TP) among all cases of the disease (TP+FN). 

 

Sensitivity = TP / TP + FN X 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It confirms that the person does not have the disease: Incorrect. A sensitive test returning a positive result indicates the presence, not the absence, of the disease.

 

Option B. It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease: Incorrect. If the disease is rare, the positive predictive value (PPV) might be low, and the result may be less reliable.

 

Option D. It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent: Incorrect. While a positive result is more likely in a prevalent disease, it does not solely rely on sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive result from a highly sensitive test confirms the presence of the disease, particularly when the disease is common.

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife is tasked with organizing a vaccination camp within a rural community. She has been provided with 2 vials that have been unsealed. Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

 

According to the Open Vial Policy, certain vaccines can be used for subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks after opening, provided they have been stored properly and are not expired. This policy helps to minimize vaccine wastage and ensure efficient use of available vaccines.

 

Open Vial Policy (2015)

 

  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UPTO 4 WEEKS’
  • Open vial policy – 
    • Applicable for - Hep B, OPV, DPT, Liquid pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV, HiB
    • Not applicable for - BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid-19 vaccines
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Under the Open Vial Policy, the auxiliary nurse midwife can use the pentavalent vaccine for subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks after opening, but must discard the MR vaccine as it does not fall under the Open Vial Policy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old demographer describes the demographic transition of a European nation currently in the 5th stage of its demographic cycle. Which of the following statements best describes the country's demographic characteristics in this stage? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Birth rate < Death rate

 

In the context of the demographic transition model, the 5th stage is characterized by a situation where the birth rate falls below the death rate. This leads to a natural decrease in population size.

 

Demographic Cycle:

 

Stage 1: (high stationary): High birth rate & high death rate

 

Stage 2: (early expanding): Birth rate unchanged & death rate decrease

 

Stage3: (late expanding): Birth rate: decreases &death rate: decreases

 

Stage 4: (late stationary): Br: low & dr: low

 

Stage 5: (declining): Br < dr/ population decreases

 

 

Minimum demographic gap: Stage 1 & stage 4

 

Maximum demographic gap: Late part of stage 2

 

India is in: Stage 3 (late expanding stage)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate is unchanged: This does not characterize any specific stage of demographic transition accurately.

 

Option B. Death rate declines: This typically occurs in the early stages (Stage 2 and 3) of the demographic transition.

 

Option D. Positive demographic gap: This indicates a situation where the birth rate is higher than the death rate, leading to population growth, typical of Stage 2 and early Stage 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Stage 5 of the demographic transition, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a natural decrease in population.

questions.text: Definitive Investigation for a patient of dengue who presented with features of Dengue hemorrhagic syndrome since last 5 days is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RT-PCR

 

RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most definitive investigation for diagnosing dengue, particularly in the first five days of illness. RT-PCR is highly sensitive and specific, capable of detecting the viral RNA present in the blood.

 

Although NS1 antigen detection is another option for early diagnosis, RT-PCR provides more reliable results, especially around the 3rd day of illness.

 

Studies indicate that within the first five days, RT-PCR is superior to the NS1 antigen test in detecting dengue infection. After five days, when the viral RNA levels decrease, ELISA IgM becomes a more suitable test as it detects the presence of antibodies developed against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS-1 antigen: The NS1 antigen test is useful in the early diagnosis of dengue, typically within the first few days of illness. However, it is most effective around the 2nd day of illness and is less reliable compared to RT-PCR by the 5th day.

 

Option C. Viral culture: Viral culture is not typically used in clinical settings for the diagnosis of dengue because it is time-consuming, requires specialized facilities, and is less practical for rapid diagnosis.

 

Option D. ELISA IgM: ELISA IgM is a serological test that detects antibodies produced in response to dengue infection. It becomes more effective after 5 days of illness, when the immune response is more developed, making it unsuitable for diagnosis within the first five days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms within the first five days, RT-PCR is the definitive diagnostic test due to its high sensitivity and ability to detect viral RNA during this critical period.

questions.text: You are a public health officer in a remote village experiencing a rise in dog bites due to an increase in stray dogs. The local panchayat asks you to teach the villagers essential first aid steps after a dog bite. Which method would you primarily use? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Demonstration

 

Performing the method of washing the wound in front of the villagers will be the best way to teach them. This method is called Demonstration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panel discussion: Best for discussing various viewpoints but not ideal for teaching practical skills.

 

Option B. Flash cards: Useful for quick information and reminders but not as effective for demonstrating practical steps.

 

Option D. Symposium: Suitable for delivering in-depth information and discussions but not for practical demonstrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demonstration is the most effective method for teaching practical first aid steps, such as wound care after a dog bite, especially in settings with limited healthcare access.

questions.text: A health economist aims to compare the overall well-being and life expectancy between two countries. He uses a specific index which considers life expectancy, education, and per capita income. Which of the following measures has he most likely utilized for his comparison? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HDI

 

HDI (Human Development Index) is used to compare life expectancy between two countries because HDI has life expectancy as one of its components.

 

HDI is a composite index comprising of 3 dimensions: 

 

  • Knowledge

 

 

  • Income
  • Longevity

 

HDI is Geometric mean of 3 dimension indices

 

HDI values range: 0 to + 1

 

HDI India is 0.644 (Rank 134 out of 189 countries)

 

Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Other Options:

 

HPI (Human Poverty Index), QALY (Quality adjusted life years), DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years) does not have life expectancy in its components.

 

Option B. HPI (Human Poverty Index): HPI is a measure that was introduced by the United Nations to assess the standard of living in a country. It considers variables such as the probability of not surviving past age 40, adult illiteracy rate, and lack of access to clean water and health services. While it does give information about well-being, it does not directly compare life expectancies. HDI is a measure of development, whereas HPI is a measure of its deprivation

 

Option C. DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Year): DALY is a measure used to assess the overall disease burden in a specific population. It considers both years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with disability. It doesn't compare life expectancies between countries but rather assesses the impact of specific diseases.

 

Option D. QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year): QALY is a measure used in health economics to assess the value of medical interventions. It combines both the quality and the quantity of life lived. It's used to assess the cost-effectiveness of a specific medical treatment but not to compare life expectancies between countries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HDI is a vital tool for comparing holistic human development levels across countries, incorporating health, education, and income, thus providing a multidimensional view of societal progress.

questions.text: During your residency, you learn about a specific protocol essential for physicians when dealing with challenging scenarios. This protocol, known as the SPIKES protocol, serves a unique purpose in medical communication. Can you identify the primary objective of employing the SPIKES protocol? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breaking bad news

 

SPIKES PROTOCOL

 

  • Communication of cancer Diagnosis & Prognosis (or any adverse outcome)
  • Protocol of 6 steps

S - Set up interview

P - Perceptions

I - Invitation to explain

K - Knowledge

E - Emotions

S - Summary & Strategy

 

Best used for Communication of diagnosis and prognosis for Breast Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triage: Incorrect. Triage involves prioritizing patient care based on the severity of their condition.

 

Option B. Consent for study participation: Incorrect. Obtaining consent for study participation requires a different communication protocol focused on informed consent.

 

Option C. Hospital infection control: Incorrect. Infection control involves protocols for preventing and managing infections within the hospital setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SPIKES protocol is specifically designed to guide physicians in breaking bad news to patients, ensuring the communication is handled with sensitivity and clarity.

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Thirst

 

Thirst is recognized as the most reliable feature of some dehydration. When dehydration begins to set in, the body's initial response is to signal thirst as a way to encourage fluid intake. This response is consistent across various cases of mild to moderate dehydration. Unlike other symptoms, thirst is a direct and early indicator of dehydration that can be easily recognized by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: Skin turgor, or the delayed return of the skin to its normal position after being pinched, is influenced by several factors, including nutritional status. This makes it less reliable as a sole indicator of dehydration.

 

Option B. Lethargy: Lethargy can be a symptom of dehydration, but it is difficult to quantify and may vary widely depending on the individual's overall health and the severity of dehydration.

 

Option D. Sunken eyes: The appearance of sunken eyes is quite subjective and often requires the input of a caregiver, such as a parent, to determine whether it is present. It is also not always a definitive sign of dehydration, making it less reliable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

questions.text: Total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of same reproductive age is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TFR (Total Fertility Rate)

 

Explanation:

 

The total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group is referred to as the Total Fertility Rate (TFR).

 

The following definitions are provided:

 

  • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman
  • GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan
  • NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths)
  • GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because NRR takes into account the mortality of the girls born, not the total number of children born to a woman.

 

Option C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because GFR is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group, not the total number of children born to an individual woman.

 

Option D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because GRR specifically refers to the number of girls born to a woman, not the total number of children born.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the measure that represents the total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group.

questions.text: Ottawa Charter includes all except: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potentiate

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion, established in 1986, outlines five key action areas essential for health promotion: building healthy public policy, creating supportive environments, strengthening community action, developing personal skills, and reorienting health services.

 

In addition to these action areas, the Ottawa Charter emphasizes three fundamental strategies for health promotion: advocate, enable, and mediate. These strategies are aimed at fostering conditions that promote health and well-being, empowering individuals and communities, and facilitating partnerships among various sectors to achieve health goals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advocate: Advocacy is a core strategy of the Ottawa Charter aimed at creating conditions conducive to health by influencing public policy and resource allocation.

 

Option B. Enable: Enabling involves empowering people to achieve their fullest health potential by providing equitable access to resources and opportunities.

 

Option D. Mediate: Mediation focuses on coordinating actions among various sectors and stakeholders to resolve conflicts and achieve consensus for health promotion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion includes the strategies of advocate, enable, and mediate, but does not include potentiate.

questions.text:
To study the effect of Vitamin C consumption on the occurrence of Respiratory disease, arrange the steps of a case-control study in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]


1 – Measurement of exposure.
2 – Matching.
3 – Analysis and interpretation.
4 – Selection of cases and controls.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4-2-1-3

 
A case-control study is a retrospective observational study design commonly used to investigate the causes of a condition or disease. The steps are as follows:

 

4. Selection of cases and controls : The first step involves identifying the cases (individuals with the disease) and controls (individuals without the disease). In this example, cases would be people with respiratory disease, and controls would be those without it.

 

2. Matching : The next step is to match the cases and controls on various confounding factors such as age, gender, or lifestyle to minimize bias.

 

1. Measurement of exposure : After matching, the history of exposure to the risk factor (in this case, Vitamin C consumption) is measured for both cases and controls by collecting historical data.

 

3. Analysis and interpretation : Finally, data is analyzed, often using a 2x2 table to calculate the odds ratio, which determines the association between the exposure and the disease. An odds ratio greater than 1 indicates a positive association, less than 1 indicates a protective effect, and equal to 1 indicates no association.

 

Educational Objective:


The correct sequence of steps in a case-control study is: Selection of cases and controls, matching, measurement of exposure, and then analysis and interpretation.

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.text: To accurately calculate the perinatal mortality rate, which of the following should specifically be considered as part of the numerator? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g 

 

Perinatal Mortality Rate (PNMR)

 

  • It includes both late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.

 

 

  • Perinatal period is from 28 weeks period of gestation to 7th completed days of life (But the WHO definition of perinatal period is from 22 completed weeks gestation to 7th completed days of life).
  • PNMR is a major marker to assess the quality of health care delivery; PNMR is a” Yardstick of Obstetric and Pediatric care before and around the time of birth”
  • P List (ICD 10): 100 causes of perinatal mortality and morbidity
  • PNMR of India (2022) - 18 per 1000 LB (SRS, September 2022)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perinatal mortality rate includes late fetal deaths (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths, focusing on the period from 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth.

questions.text: In a clinical study exploring the relationship between variables X and Y, a scatter plot with a linear regression line has been generated. Based on the graphical representation provided, which of the following equations corresponds to the linear regression model of the plotted graph? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) y=11+2x

 

  • Y = 11 + 2x is a simple linear regression equation where a = 11 and b = 2 are constants and x and y are variables.
  • Regression is change in measurements of a variable. It provides structure of relationship between 2 quantitative variables.

 

Types of regressions:

 

  • Simple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable
  • Multiple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variable
  • Simple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable, with some power of independent variable
  • Multiple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variables, with some power of independent variables).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of regression equations:

questions.text: Calculate Maternal Mortality Ratio in a population of 2 lacs, with 4000 live births, Death were 4 by PPH, 2 deaths by electrocution, 2 deaths by sepsis, 2 deaths by abortion, 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, and 5 still births. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 250 per 1 lac

 

Explanation:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

 

Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days of delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.

 

In the given scenario, the maternal deaths are:

 

  • 4 deaths by postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
  • 2 deaths by sepsis
  • 2 deaths by abortion
  • 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy

 

These deaths should be included in the calculation as they are related to maternity or its complications.

 

The deaths due to electrocution and stillbirths are not included in the calculation of MMR.

 

Therefore, the total number of maternal deaths is 10 (4 + 2 + 2 + 2).

 

The number of live births is given as 4,000.

 

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) × 100,000

 

= (10 / 4,000) × 100,000

 

= 250 per 1,00,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths (deaths related to maternity or its complications) by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

questions.text: As the member of a school health committee, you are revising the school health program to improve student well-being. Which of the following is NOT a standard component of school health? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Doctor on school premises

 

School health service includes all the above except the presence of a doctor in the school premises.

 

In 1961, ‘Renuka Roy School Health Committee’ laid the foundations for a comprehensive school health programme in India. School health committee (1961) in India recommended medical examination of children ‘at the time of entry and thereafter every 4 years’ [New NRHM guideline: Once every 6 months]. 

 

School health checkup comes under Secondary level of prevention

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teaching handicapped children: This is an essential part of ensuring that all students, including those with disabilities, receive appropriate education and support.

 

Option C. Dental and eye health services: Regular dental and eye check-ups are standard components of school health programs to identify and address common health issues.

 

Option D. School health records: Maintaining health records is crucial for tracking the health and well-being of students over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School Health Program includes:

 

  • Screening of general health assessment of visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up etc.
  • First-aid and emergency care
  • Education of handicapped children
  • Health education
  • Maintenance and use of school health records

choices.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid
Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine
If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

 

  • Dose of Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIg): 20 IU/kg body weight
  • Dose of Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (ERIg): 40 IU/kg body weight
  • RIg must be given as soon as possible
  • RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine
  • RIg must never be given Intravenously
  • Entire dose of RIg (or as much as possible) must be infiltrated around the wound(s) site(s).
  • Remaining dose, if any, must be given Intramuscularly in deltoid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between height and weight in a specific population. She decides to utilize a cluster sampling method to streamline the data collection process. After analyzing data from four distinct clusters, each one consistently demonstrates a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight. Based on this information, what can the researcher expect about the overall correlation coefficient when combining data from all four clusters? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Equal to 0.6

 

  • When each cluster independently shows a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight, the overall correlation coefficient for the combined data will also be 0.6.
  • This is because the correlation coefficient measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, and consistent values across clusters will result in the same overall correlation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCATTER/DOT DIAGRAM

 

  • Also known as ‘Correlation diagram
  • Is used to depict ‘correlation (relationship) between 2 quantitative variables
  • Vertical axis in scatter diagram: should be the dependent or the outcome variable
  • In a scatter diagram, 2 imaginary lines are drawn along the distribution of dots/ scatter.

choices.text: No of those getting adequate treatment

questions.text: In the Rule of halves phenomenon (See image below), Mark what is represented by innermost circle (black color)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No of those getting adequate treatment

 

Explanation:

 

The rule of halves is a phenomenon applicable to hypertension, which states that as blood pressure increases with age, roughly 50% of the adult population will have hypertension at any given point in time.

The image shows concentric circles representing different subsets of the population with hypertension. the innermost black circle represents the number of people who are getting adequate treatment for their hypertension. This is 50% of the subset who seek treatment, which is itself 50% of those who are symptomatic, who are in turn 50% of the total number of people with hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No of hypertensives: This option is incorrect because the number of hypertensives is represented by the yellow circle, which is the second outermost circle, not the innermost black circle.

 

Option B. No of those symptomatic: This option is incorrect because the number of those symptomatic is represented by the green circle, which is the third outermost circle, not the innermost black circle.

 

Option C. No of those seeking treatment: This option is incorrect because the number of those seeking treatment is represented by the red circle, which is the second innermost circle, not the innermost black circle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the rule of halves phenomenon for hypertension, the innermost circle represents the number of people who are getting adequate treatment, which is only 50% of the subset who seek treatment, highlighting the need for improved hypertension management.

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a given population, total births in a year are 4050. There are 50 stillbirths. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, whereas the number of deaths within 8-28 days of life is 150. What is the neonatal mortality rate in the population?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 50

 

Explanation:

 

The neonatal mortality rate is calculated by dividing the total number of neonatal deaths (deaths within 0-28 days of life) by the total number of live births and multiplying the result by 1,000.

 

Given:

 

  • Total births in a year = 4050
  • Stillbirths = 50
  • Neonatal deaths within the first 7 days (early neonatal period) = 50
  • Neonatal deaths within 8-28 days (late neonatal period) = 150

 

Step 1: Calculate the number of live births.

Number of live births = Total births - Stillbirths

Number of live births = 4050 - 50 = 4000

 

Step 2: Calculate the total number of neonatal deaths.

Total neonatal deaths = Neonatal deaths within the first 7 days + Neonatal deaths within 8-28 days

Total neonatal deaths = 50 + 150 = 200

 

Step 3: Calculate the neonatal mortality rate using the formula:

Neonatal mortality rate = (Total neonatal deaths / Total live births) × 1000

Neonatal mortality rate = (200 / 4000) × 1000

Neonatal mortality rate = 50 per 1,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neonatal mortality rate is a crucial indicator that represents the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within 0-28 days of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population. It encompasses both early neonatal deaths (within the first 7 days) and late neonatal deaths (8-28 days).

questions.text: Recommended minimum per capita space for a factory worker as per The Factory Act 1948 is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 500 cu feet

 

The Factory Act of 1948 is a key piece of legislation in India that governs the working conditions in factories. The recommended minimum per capita space for a factory worker according to this act is 500 cubic feet. This requirement is essential to ensure adequate ventilation and prevent the spread of communicable diseases, as well as to improve overall working conditions.

 

The Factories Act, 1948

 

  • Scope: The Act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more persons where power is used and 20 or more persons where power is not used
  • Work related norms:
    • Employment of young persons:
      • Employment prohibited for age less than 14 years
      • 15-18 years old adolescents to be declared fit by ‘certifying surgeons’; will work only between 6AM to 7PM
      • Employment prohibited in certain dangerous occupations
    • Hours of work:
      • A maximum of 4½ hours of work per day for adolescents
      • 48 hours per week (9 hrs per day)
      • Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime)
    • Leave with wages:
      • 1 day per 15 days of work for adolescents
      • Leaves can be accumulated up to 40 days
    • Health, Safety and Welfare recommendations:
      • A minimum of 500 cubic feet space per worker
      • 1 Safety Officer per 1000 workers
      • 1 Welfare Officer per 500 workers
      • 1 Canteen for greater than 250 workers
      • 1 Crèche for greater than 30 women workers
    • Under Factories Act 1948, there are 29 diseases which are notifiable (Schedule 3): Silicosis; Anthracosis; Byssinosis and Asbestosis
    • Exclusions from the Factory Act: The act does not apply to four specific sectors: the defense sector, mines, railways, and food joints or eateries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended spaces:

 

  • Floor space per person in a house: minimum 70 – 90 sq. ft.
  • Floor area per student in a class: > 10 sq. ft.
  • Space per worker in a factory (The Factory Act, 1948): >500 cu. ft.t

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) VVM

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a rash after a trip. You observe a vector on his skin. Considering common vector-borne diseases, what is the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image. ([INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The image provided shows a trombiculid mite, which is commonly involved in the transmission of Scrub Typhus.

 

  • Scrub Typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is primarily transmitted through bites of infected chiggers. The disease is prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region, so exposure in those areas following a rash and the sighting of a trombiculid mite on the skin strongly points to Scrub Typhus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babesiosis: This is transmitted by Ixodes ticks (deer ticks), affecting red blood cells similar to malaria. It is not related to trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Anaplasmosis: Transmitted by deer ticks and the western black-legged tick, this disease targets white blood cells. It's also not transmitted by trombiculid mites.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: This disease is transmitted by ticks like the lone star tick and affects white blood cells. It does not involve trombiculid mites.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Scrub Typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mites, specifically the chigger larvae. It is characterized by fever, rash, and a black eschar at the site of the mite bite.

 

DOC – Doxycycline (monotherapy)

 

If severe manifestations – Doxycycline + Azithromycin

questions.text: A patient presents with flu-like symptoms after a camping trip and multiple insect bites. You suspect a vector-borne illness. Which pathogen is likely if the vector is a Trombiculid mite? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • Above given image depicts Trombiculid mite, which transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi. It causes scrub typhus disease in humans.

 

 

  • Life cycle of Trombiculid mite with transovarial transmission

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Kyasanur forest disease virus: Kyasanur forest disease virus is transmitted by hard tick

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is an Arbovirus transmitted by Sand fly (Phlebotomus)

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma phagocytophilia: Anaplasma phagocytophilia (formerly Ehrlichia phagocytophilum) is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes an acute febrile illness known as anaplasmosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Orientia tsutsugamushi, transmitted by Trombiculid mites, causes scrub typhus.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: No of live births per 1000 women in reproductive age group is?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) General fertility rate

 

Explanation:

 

The general fertility rate is defined as the total number of live births in a community in a year divided by the total number of women in the reproductive age group (usually 15-49 years) per 1,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total fertility rate (TFR): Incorrect. TFR refers to the total number of children born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan.

 

Option C. Age specific fertility rate (ASFR): Incorrect. Age-specific fertility rate is the fertility rate calculated for a given age interval, usually 5 years, per 1,000 mid-year population.

 

Option D. Gross reproduction rate: Incorrect. Gross reproduction rate (GRR) is the total number of girl children born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan at current ASFRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The general fertility rate is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group (usually 15-49 years) in a given year.

 

Note - Net reproduction rate (NRR): Expected number of daughters, per newborn prospective mother, who may or may not survive to and through the ages of childbearing.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to your clinic after a dog bite earlier in the day. Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm abrasion with some oozing. Given the nature of the wound and the potential interventions post-exposure, which combination of actions and descriptors best characterizes the appropriate management? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Category 3 wound
  2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes
  3. Clean the wound with spirit
  4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing
  5. Equine immunoglobin is given at a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice
  6. Intra-dermal vaccine is administered on days 0, 3, 7, 28
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 2, 3, 6

 

The patient with a dog bite presented with an abrasion, which comes under category 3 wound.

 

The components of post–exposure prophylaxis are:

 

  1. Local treatment of wound
  2. Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures
  3. Active immunization against rabies – if indicated
  4. Passive immunization with rabies immunoglobulin – if indicated
  5. Observe the animal for 10 days from the day of bite:
    • If healthy after 10 days: Discontinue post – exposure vaccination
    • If dies within observation period: complete PEP
    • If observation not possible: complete the post – exposure vaccination

 

Other Option: 

 

Statement 4 – Abrasion wound doesn’t require suturing

 

Statement 5 – Equine Rabies Ig at dose of 40 IU/kg should be given only once.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A researcher in epidemiology is planning to conduct a meta-analysis to better understand the effects of a specific intervention. While he lists the various stages and processes associated with a meta-analysis, he includes one element that isn't typically involved in a meta-analysis. Which of the following isn't directly associated with the process of a meta-analysis? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Randomization 

 

  • Randomization is not a part of the meta-analysis process but is a critical component of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which may be included in a meta-analysis.
  • Meta-analysis involves analysis of multiple studies together.
  • Steps of Meta-analysis involves Hypothesis formation, Study selection, Formulation of data, Analysis of data, examining bias, formulating conclusion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selection: Involves selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Option B. Analysis: Involves statistical analysis of the combined data from the selected studies.

 

Option D. Abstraction: Involves extracting data from the studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Randomization is a part of conducting individual randomized controlled trials, not the process of performing a meta-analysis.

choices.text: Kwashiorkor due to less energy intake
Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake
Marasmus due to less energy intake
Marasmus due to less protein intake

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by her grandmother Which of the following is correct about the given image? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake

 

The given image is suggestive of kwashiorkor, as it shows a bulging abdomen and pedal edema along with thin limbs and prominent ribs. Kwashiorkor occurs as a result of less protein intake, whereas marasmus occurs due to less calorie intake.

questions.text: Which of the following is disposed in the yellow bag? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood bag

 

Blood bag is disposed in the yellow bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gloves: Red bag.

 


Option C.  Sharps: White container.

 

Option D. Urine bags: Red bag.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with wounds that aren’t healing properly, diarrhea, alopecia, and dermatitis. This could be due to which nutrient deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

 Zinc deficiency, also known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, is characterized by symptoms such as impaired wound healing, diarrhea, alopecia, and dermatitis.

Zinc is crucial for immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. A deficiency in zinc disrupts these biological processes, leading to the symptoms mentioned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Deficiency leads to scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums, weakness, and bruising, not primarily with the symptoms listed in the question.

 

Option C. Niacin: Deficiency results in pellagra, characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and eventually death, but does not typically include alopecia as a primary symptom.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Deficiency can cause neurological and muscular symptoms, such as tremors and muscle spasms, which are not mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of diarrhea, impaired wound healing, alopecia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: What are the stages of demographic cycle with same birth rate but variable death rate?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stage 1 + stage 2

 

Explanation: 

 

The demographic transition model consists of five stages, each characterized by different levels of crude birth rates (CBR) and crude death rates (CDR). In stages 1 and 2, the birth rate remains high, while the death rate varies.

 

 

Stage 1 (High Stationary): In this stage, both the CBR (green line) and CDR (red line) are very high, resulting in a relatively stable population size.

 

Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The CBR remains high, but the CDR starts declining due to improvements in medical facilities, more hospitals, and more doctors. This leads to population growth.

 

Other Options:

 

In stage 3 (Late Expanding), the CBR starts declining for the first time due to the introduction of family planning programs, while the CDR continues to decrease. India is currently in this stage.

 

In stage 4 (Low Stationary), both the CBR and CDR are low, resulting in a stable population. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

 

In stage 5 (Declining), the CBR falls below the CDR, leading to population reduction. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In stages 1 and 2 of the demographic transition model, the crude birth rate remains high, while the crude death rate is high in stage 1 but starts declining in stage 2, making these the stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

questions.text: A man lives with his pregnant wife and a child under 3 years old. His brother and his wife are staying with them for a month. How should this family be categorized? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nuclear family

 

A nuclear family, also known as an elementary or unitary family, consists of a married couple and their children who are still regarded as dependents. In this scenario, the core members are the man, his pregnant wife, and their young child, fitting the definition of a nuclear family.

 

Even though the man's brother and his wife are temporarily staying with them, this does not change the fundamental structure of the family. The temporary presence of additional relatives does not convert a nuclear family into an extended or joint family unless these additional members become permanent residents and contribute to the common household in a sustained manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extended family: An extended family includes additional relatives living together permanently. In this case, the brother and his wife are not permanent residents.

 

Option C. Joint family: A joint family consists of multiple married couples and their children living together permanently, holding property in common, and typically being managed by the senior male member. This structure includes familial relations that enjoy primacy over marital relations, which is not applicable here due to the temporary nature of the brother’s stay.

 

Option D. Third generation: A three-generation family includes representatives from three generations living together in one household. This scenario does not include a third generation (e.g., grandparents).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nuclear family consists of parents and their children, even if other relatives are temporarily staying with them.

questions.text: According to the current biomedical waste management guidelines, which colored bin should be used for the disposal of blood bag? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow bin 

 

  • Yellow Bin: Used for human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, and clinical lab waste.
  • This includes items such as body parts, blood bags, and items contaminated with body fluids.
  • The disposal methods typically involve incineration, plasma pyrolysis, deep burial, or chemical treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by the intake of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea

 

Explanation:

 

There are several factors that can decrease iron absorption, including phytates (present in cereals and legumes), tannates (present in tea, coffee, and soft drinks), oxalates (present in milk and eggs), and certain medications like tetracycline.

 

The only facilitator of iron absorption is vitamin C or ascorbic acid.

 

Among the given options, tea contains tannates, which are known to inhibit iron absorption. Therefore, the intake of tea decreases iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amla: This option is incorrect because amla is a rich source of vitamin C, which enhances iron absorption.

 

Option B. Sprouts: This option is incorrect because sprouts are a good source of iron.

 

Option D. Lemon: This option is incorrect because lemon is a source of vitamin C, which facilitates iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea contains tannates, which are compounds that inhibit iron absorption. Consuming tea can decrease the absorption of iron from dietary sources.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, the land area necessary to implement the controlled tipping using the trench method is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1 acre

 

Controlled tipping or controlled burial is similar in principle to sanitary landfill but at a smaller scale that is appropriate in rural areas. 

 

Trench Method— The waste collection truck deposits its load into the trench where the bulldozer spreads and compacts it. Approximately, 1 acre of land is required for a population of 10000 for a depth of 2 feet and usable for 1-year duration

 

Educational Objective:

 

For implementing controlled tipping using the trench method, 1 acre of land is sufficient for a population of 10,000, considering a depth of 2 feet and a usage duration of one year.

questions.text: Which one of these is not used for body fat evaluation? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breslow index 

 

  • The Breslow index is a measurement used specifically in dermatology to determine the depth of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. 
  • It measures the thickness of the tumor and is critical for staging the cancer and determining treatment and prognosis. Therefore, it is not related to the assessment of body fat or overall body composition.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Quetelet's index:  This is another name for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is widely used to estimate body fat based on an individual's weight and height. It provides a useful general indicator of health risks associated with body fat levels.
 

Option B. Total body potassium: This measure is used to estimate body cell mass and, indirectly, muscle mass, since potassium is primarily found in muscle tissue. Total body potassium can be an indicator of body composition, including body fat.
 

Option C. Total body water: This is used to assess hydration status and body composition. The amount of water in the body can be indicative of muscle mass (which holds a high water content) compared to fat (which holds less), thus providing insights into body fat levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Breslow index assesses the depth of melanoma skin cancer. It is crucial to recognize that this index serves a specific purpose in clinical dermatology and oncology, unrelated to nutritional or fitness assessments.

 

Obesity indices are –

 

  • Broca’s Index: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) – 100
  • Quetelet’s Index (Body Mass Index /BMI): BMI = Weight (kg) / Height (m)2
  • Corpulence Index (CI) = Actual weight/Desirable weight
  • Ponderal Index (PI)

questions.text: Triage is categorization of victims of Disaster. Correct match for the categories of Triage is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yellow – Stable, Need observation

 

Explanation:

 

Triage is the process of sorting and categorizing victims based on the likelihood of survival and the urgency of their need for medical treatment.

Triage categorizes victims to prioritize treatment based on the urgency and likelihood of survival, with yellow indicating stable patients who need observation but can wait for treatment.

Yellow is the Minimal Category

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red – Least priority: This is incorrect as red indicates the highest priority, requiring immediate intervention (Emergency category).

 

Option B. Black – Minor injuries, Immediate priority: This is incorrect as black represents deceased or moribund patients, not those with minor injuries.

 

Option D. Green – Life threatening: This is incorrect as green indicates minor injuries that are not life-threatening and can wait for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a disaster, victims are categorized into four primary colors:

 

  • Red: This category includes patients who require immediate resuscitation or life/limb-saving surgery within 0-6 hours to prevent death.
  • Yellow: These patients may require resuscitation or life/limb-saving surgery, but their treatment can be delayed up to 6-24 hours without immediate risk to life.
  • Green: These patients have minor, non-life-threatening injuries such as small fractures, abrasions, bruises, or lacerations. They are ambulatory and can wait for medical care.
  • Black: This category includes deceased or moribund patients who are beyond the possibility of resuscitation.

questions.text: The preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between two study groups, where one group functions as a control, is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Unpaired t test

 

When comparing the means of two independent groups, where one group serves as a control, the appropriate statistical test to use is the unpaired t-test. This test is designed to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of the two independent groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: This test is used for categorical data to assess whether there is a significant association between two variables.

 

Option B. Z test: The Z test is typically used for large sample sizes to compare the means of two populations or to test proportions.

 

Option D. Paired T test: The paired t-test is used when comparing means from the same group at different times or under different conditions (e.g., before and after treatment).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • The formula given represents the standard deviation, which measures the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
  • It is the square root of the variance, where the variance is the average of the squared differences from the mean.
  • Standard deviation: This is the deviation of each value from the standard value (mean). It provides insight into the spread of the data points around the mean.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance = (Standard deviation)2. It represents the average of the squared deviations from the mean.

 

Option C. Mean is obtained as the sum of all values divided by the number of values. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Standard deviation is the deviation of each value from the standard value [Mean].

choices.text: Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman

questions.text: G5P4 lady with 4 female children reports for the first time at 18 weeks POG. As per the PCPNDT Act and Beti Bachao Andolan, what will you do? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman

 

In India, the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, 1994, strictly prohibits the determination of fetal sex to prevent female feticide. The act is a legal measure to curb the misuse of diagnostic techniques for sex determination, which could lead to gender-selective abortions. This law aligns with the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao initiative, which aims to save and educate the girl child.

 

In the given scenario, the woman is at 18 weeks of gestation. A USG (ultrasound) scan is recommended to assess fetal health and pregnancy progress but not to determine the fetus's gender. Neither the radiologist nor the obstetrician/gynecologist should attempt to determine or disclose the fetus's gender unless there is a valid legal or medical reason, which is rare and strictly controlled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Don’t do the USG scan: This option is incorrect because USG is an important tool for monitoring fetal development and maternal health. Refusing to perform a USG scan without medical justification would be inappropriate and neglectful of standard prenatal care.

 

Option C. Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman:  This option is incorrect because, under the PCPNDT Act, healthcare professionals are prohibited from determining the gender of the fetus during a USG scan unless medically indicated. Viewing the fetus's gender without a valid reason is a violation of the law.

 

Option D.  Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman: This option is incorrect and illegal as per the PCPNDT Act. Disclosing the gender of the fetus to the expectant mother or any other person is punishable by law, as it could lead to gender-based discrimination and sex-selective abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal sex determination and disclosure are illegal under the PCPNDT Act unless medically indicated. During routine prenatal care, USG should be performed without determining or revealing the fetus's gender.
